Based on the information available, let’s analyze your NVIDIA driver version 535.247.01 and CUDA version 12.2.

NVIDIA Driver Version 535.247.01:

  • This driver version was released around April 17, 2025.
  • It is associated with the R535 driver branch for Linux and is also listed as a Long Term Stable Branch (LTSB) driver.
  • For Windows, the latest driver in the R535 branch appears to be 539.28, also released around the same time.
  • The latest GeForce driver across all branches is 576.52 WHQL, released on May 19, 2025.
  • Therefore, driver version 535.247.01 is not the latest available GeForce driver. However, it is the latest within its specific R535 LTSB branch for Linux as of the information available.

CUDA Version 12.2:

  • CUDA Toolkit 12.2 was released around June 2023.
  • There have been subsequent updates to CUDA 12.2, with the latest being CUDA Toolkit 12.2 Update 2, released in August 2023.
  • More recent major CUDA versions have also been released since then, including CUDA 12.3, 12.4, 12.5, 12.6, and the latest being CUDA Toolkit 12.8.1 released in March 2025.
  • Therefore, CUDA version 12.2 is not the latest version.

In summary:

  • Your driver version 535.247.01 is the most recent within the R535 Long Term Stable Branch for Linux but is not the absolute latest GeForce driver available.
  • Your CUDA version 12.2 is not the latest CUDA Toolkit version.

It’s generally recommended to use the latest drivers for optimal performance, bug fixes, and new feature support, especially if you are a gamer or content creator. Similarly, using the latest CUDA Toolkit can provide access to the newest features and improvements for GPU-accelerated computing. However, Long Term Stable Branch drivers can be preferred in enterprise environments for their reliability over frequent updates.

You can always check the official NVIDIA website to see the latest drivers and CUDA Toolkit versions available for your specific hardware and operating system.
